Privacy Against Inference Attacks in Vertical Federated Learning

Borzoo Rassouli1, Morteza Varasteh1 and Deniz Gündüz2
1 School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering, University of Essex, Colchester CO4 3SQ, UK
2 Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, , London SW7 2AZ, UK
{b.rassouli,m.varasteh}@essex.ac.uk, d.gunduz@imperial.ac.uk
Abstract

Vertical federated learning is considered, where an active party, having access to true class labels, wishes to build a classification model by utilizing more features from a passive party, which has no access to the labels, to improve the model accuracy. In the prediction phase, with logistic regression as the classification model, several inference attack techniques are proposed that the adversary, i.e., the active party, can employ to reconstruct the passive party’s features, regarded as sensitive information. These attacks, which are mainly based on a classical notion of the center of a set, i.e., the Chebyshev center, are shown to be superior to those proposed in the literature. Moreover, several theoretical performance guarantees are provided for the aforementioned attacks. Subsequently, we consider the minimum amount of information that the adversary needs to fully reconstruct the passive party’s features. In particular, it is shown that when the passive party holds one feature, and the adversary is only aware of the signs of the parameters involved, it can perfectly reconstruct that feature when the number of predictions is large enough. Next, as a defense mechanism, several privacy-preserving schemes are proposed that worsen the adversary’s reconstruction attacks, while preserving the benefits that VFL brings to the active party. Finally, experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed attacks and the privacy-preserving schemes.

I introduction

To tackle the concerns in the traditional centralized learning, i.e., privacy, storage, and computational complexity, Federated Learning (FL) has been proposed in [1] where machine learning (ML) models are jointly trained by multiple local data owners (i.e., parties), such as smart phones, data centres, etc., without revealing their private data to each other. This approach has gained interest in many real-life applications, such as health systems [2, 3], keyboard prediction [4, 5], and e-commerce [6, 7].

Based on how data is partitioned among participating parties, three variants of FL, which are horizontal, vertical and transfer FL, have been considered. Horizontal FL (HFL) refers to the FL among data owners that share different data records/samples with the same set of features [8], and vertical FL (VFL) is the FL in which parties share common data samples with disjoint set of features [9].

Figure 1 illustrates a digital banking system as an example of a VFL setting, in which two parties are participating, namely, a bank and a FinTech company [10]. The bank wishes to build a binary classification model to approve/disapprove a user’s credit card application by utilizing more features from the Fintech company. In this context, only the bank has access to the class labels in the training and testing datasets, hence named the active party, and the FinTech company that is unaware of the labels is referred to as the passive party.

Once the model is trained, it can be used to predict the decision (approve/disapprove) on a new credit card application in the prediction dataset. The model outputs, referred to as the prediction outputs or more specifically, the confidence scores, are revealed to the active party that is in charge of making decision. The active party maybe aware or unaware of the passive party’s model parameters, which are, respectively, referred to as the white-box and black-box settings.

As stated in [10], upon the receipt of the prediction outputs, which generally depend on the passive party’s features, a curious active party can perform reconstruction attacks to infer the latter, which are regarded as passive the party’s sensitive information 111The active party is also referred to as the adversary in this paper.. This privacy leakage in the prediction phase of VFL is the main focus of this paper, and the following contributions are made.

  • •

    In the white-box setting, several reconstruction attacks are proposed that outperform those given in [10],[11]. The attacks are motivated by the notion of the Chebyshev center of a convex polytope.

  • •

    Theorems 1 and 2 provide theoretical bounds as rigorous guarantees for some of these attacks.

  • •

    In the black-box setting, it is shown that when the passive party holds one feature, and the adversary is aware of the signs of the parameters involved, it can still fully reconstruct the passive party’s feature given that the number of predictions is large enough.

  • •

    Several privacy-preserving schemes are proposed as a defense technique against reconstruction attacks, which have the advantage of not degrading the benefits that VFL brings to the active party.

The organization of the paper is as follows. In section II, an explanation of the system model under consideration is provided. In section III, the elementary steps that pave the way for the adversary’s attack are elaborated, and the measure by which the performance of the reconstruction attack is evaluated is provided. The analysis and derivations in this paper need some preliminaries from linear algebra and optimization. To make the text as self contained as possible, these have been provided in section IV. The main results of the paper are given in sections V to VIII. In section V, the white-box setting is considered and several attack methods are proposed and evaluated analytically. Section VI deals with the black-box setting and investigates the minimum knowledge the adversary needs to perform a successful attack. In section VII, a privacy-preserving scheme is provided that worsens the adversary’s attacks, while not altering the confidence scores revealed to it. Section VIII is devoted to the experimental evaluation of the results of this paper and comparison to those in the literature. Finally, section IX concludes the paper. To improve the readability, the notation used in this paper is provided next.

II System model

II-A Machine learning (ML)

An ML model is a function fθ:𝒳→𝒴:subscript𝑓𝜃→𝒳𝒴f_{\mathbf{\theta}}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y} parameterized by the vector θ𝜃\mathbf{\theta}, where 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} denote the input and output spaces, respectively. Supervised classification is considered in this paper, where a labeled training dataset is used to train the model.

Assume that a training dataset 𝒟train≜{(𝐱i,yi)|i∈[n]}≜subscript𝒟trainconditional-setsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{D}_{\textnormal{train}}\triangleq\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})|i\in[n]\} is given, where each 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is a d𝑑d-dimensional example/sample and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} denotes its corresponding label. Learning refers to the process of obtaining the parameter vector θ𝜃\mathbf{\theta} in the minimization of a loss function, i.e.,

minθ⁡1n​∑i=1nl​(fθ​(𝐱i),yi)+ω​(θ),subscript𝜃1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑙subscript𝑓𝜃subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜔𝜃\min_{\mathbf{\theta}}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}l(f_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{i}),y_{i})+\omega(\mathbf{\theta}), (1)

where l​(⋅,⋅)𝑙⋅⋅l(\cdot,\cdot) measures the loss of predicting fθ​(𝐱i)subscript𝑓𝜃subscript𝐱𝑖f_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{i}), while the true label is yi,i∈[n]subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛y_{i},i\in[n]. A regularization term ω​(θ)𝜔𝜃\omega(\mathbf{\theta}) can be added to the optimization to avoid overfitting.

Once the model is trained, i.e., θ𝜃\mathbf{\theta} is obtained, it can be used for the prediction of any new sample. In practice, the prediction is (probability) vector-valued, i.e., it is a vector of confidence scores as 𝐜=(c1,c2,…,ck)T𝐜superscriptsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝑘𝑇\mathbf{c}=(c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{k})^{T} with ∑ici=1,ci≥0,i∈[k]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑖0𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\sum_{i}c_{i}=1,c_{i}\geq 0,i\in[k], where cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} denotes the probability that the sample belongs to class i𝑖i, and k𝑘k denotes the number of classes. Classification can be done by choosing the class that has the highest confidence score.

In this paper, we focus on logistic regression (LR), which can be modelled as

𝐜=σ​(𝐖𝐱+𝐛),𝐜𝜎𝐖𝐱𝐛\displaystyle\mathbf{c}=\sigma(\mathbf{Wx}+\mathbf{b}), (2)

where 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} are the parameters collectively denoted as θ𝜃\mathbf{\theta}, and σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot) is the sigmoid or softmax function in the case of binary or multi-class classification, respectively.

II-B Vertical Federated Learning

VFL is a type of ML model training approach in which two or more parties are involved in the training process, such that they hold the same set of samples with disjoint set of features. The main goal in VFL is to train a model in a privacy-preserving manner, i.e., to collaboratively train a model without each party having access to other parties’ features. Typically, the training involves a trusted third party known as the coordinator authority (CA), and it is commonly assumed that only one party has access to the label information in the training and testing datasets. This party is named active and the remaining parties are called passive. Throughout this paper, we assume that only two parties are involved; one is active and the other is passive. The active party is assumed to be honest but curious, i.e., it obeys the protocols exactly, but may try to infer passive party’s features based on the information received. As a result, the active party is referred to as the adversary in this paper.

In the existing VFL frameworks, CA’s main task is to coordinate the learning process once it has been initiated by the active party. During the training, CA receives the intermediate model updates from each party, and after a set of computations, backpropagates each party’s gradient updates, separately and securely. To meet the privacy requirements of parties’ datasets, cryptographic techniques such as secure multi-party computation (SMC) [12] or homomorphic encryption (HE) [13] are used.

Once the global model is trained, upon the request of the active party for a new record prediction, each party computes the results of their model using their own features. CA aggregates these results from all the parties, obtains the prediction (confidence scores), and delivers that to the active party for further action.

As in [10], we assume that the active party has no information about the underlying distribution of the passive party’s features. However, it is assumed that the knowledge about the name, types and range of the features is available to the active party to decide whether to participate in a VFL or not.

III Problem statement

Let (𝐘T,𝐗T)Tsuperscriptsuperscript𝐘𝑇superscript𝐗𝑇𝑇(\mathbf{Y}^{T},\mathbf{X}^{T})^{T} denote a random dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t}-dimensional input sample for prediction, where the (dt−d)subscript𝑑𝑡𝑑(d_{t}-d)-dimensional 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y} and the d𝑑d-dimensional 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} correspond to the feature values held by the active and passive parties, respectively. The VFL model under consideration is LR, where the confidence score is given by 𝐜=σ​(𝐳)𝐜𝜎𝐳\mathbf{c}=\sigma(\mathbf{z}) with 𝐳=𝕎a​c​t​𝐘+𝕎p​a​s​𝐗+𝐛𝐳subscript𝕎𝑎𝑐𝑡𝐘subscript𝕎𝑝𝑎𝑠𝐗𝐛\mathbf{z}=\mathbb{W}_{act}\mathbf{Y}+\mathbb{W}_{pas}\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{b}. Denoting the number of classes in the classification task by k𝑘k, 𝕎a​c​tsubscript𝕎𝑎𝑐𝑡\mathbb{W}_{act} (with dimension k×(dt−d)𝑘subscript𝑑𝑡𝑑k\times(d_{t}-d)) and 𝕎p​a​ssubscript𝕎𝑝𝑎𝑠\mathbb{W}_{pas} (with dimension k×d𝑘𝑑k\times d) are the model parameters of the active and passive parties, respectively, and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} is the k𝑘k-dimensional bias vector. From the definition of σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot), we have

Remark 1.

It is important to note that the way to obtain a system of linear equations is not unique, but all of them are equivalent in the sense that they result in the same solution space. More specifically, let 𝐑(k−1)×(k−1)subscript𝐑𝑘1𝑘1\mathbf{R}_{(k-1)\times(k-1)} be an invertible matrix, and define 𝐀new≜𝐑𝐀≜subscript𝐀new𝐑𝐀\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}\triangleq\mathbf{RA} and 𝐛new′≜𝐑𝐛′≜subscriptsuperscript𝐛′newsuperscript𝐑𝐛′\mathbf{b}^{\prime}_{\textnormal{new}}\triangleq\mathbf{Rb}^{\prime}. We have that both 𝐀𝐗=𝐛′𝐀𝐗superscript𝐛′\mathbf{AX}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime} and 𝐀new​𝐗=𝐛new′subscript𝐀new𝐗subscriptsuperscript𝐛′new\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}_{\textnormal{new}} are equivalent.

The white-box setting refers to the scenario where the adversary is aware of (𝐖a​c​t,𝐖p​a​s,𝐛)subscript𝐖𝑎𝑐𝑡subscript𝐖𝑝𝑎𝑠𝐛(\mathbf{W}_{act},\mathbf{W}_{pas},\mathbf{b}) and the black-box setting refers to the context in which the adversary is only aware of 𝐖a​c​tsubscript𝐖𝑎𝑐𝑡\mathbf{W}_{act}.

Since the active party wishes to reconstruct the passive party’s features, one measure by which the attack performance can be evaluated is the mean square error per feature, i.e.,

MSE=1d​𝔼​[‖𝐗−𝐗^‖2],MSE1𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗^𝐗2\textnormal{MSE}=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}\left[\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}\|^{2}\right], (7)

where 𝐗^^𝐗\hat{\mathbf{X}} is the adversary’s estimate. Let N𝑁N denote the number of predictions. Assuming that these N𝑁N predictions are carried out in an i.i.d. manner, Law of Large Numbers (LLN) allows to approximate MSE by its empirical value 1N​d​∑i=1N‖𝐗i−𝐗i^‖21𝑁𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnormsubscript𝐗𝑖^subscript𝐗𝑖2\frac{1}{Nd}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\mathbf{X}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{X}_{i}}\|^{2}, since the latter converges almost surely to (7) as N𝑁N grows.555It is important to note however that in the case when the adversary’s estimates are not independent across the predictions (non-i.i.d. case) the empirical MSE is not necessarily equal to (7). In such cases, the empirical MSE is taken as the performance metric. This observation is later used in the experimental results to evaluate the performance of different reconstruction attacks.

IV Preliminaries

Throughout this paper, we are interested in solving a satisfiable666This means that at least one solution exists for this system, which is due to the context in which this problem arises. system of linear equations, in which the unknowns (features of the passive party) are in the range [0,1]01[0,1]. This can be captured by solving for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} in the equation 𝐀𝐱=𝐛𝐀𝐱𝐛\mathbf{Ax}=\mathbf{b}, where 𝐀∈ℝm×d𝐀superscriptℝ𝑚𝑑\mathbf{A}\in\mathds{R}^{m\times d}, 𝐱∈[0,1]d𝐱superscript01𝑑\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{d}, and 𝐛∈ℝm𝐛superscriptℝ𝑚\mathbf{b}\in\mathds{R}^{m} for some positive integers m,d𝑚𝑑m,d. We are particularly interested in the case when the number of unknowns d𝑑d is greater than the number of equations m𝑚m. This is a particular case of an indeterminate/under-determined system, where 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} does not have full column rank and an infinitude of solutions exists for this linear system. Since the system under consideration is satisfiable, any solution can be written as 𝐀+​𝐛+(𝐈d−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐰superscript𝐀𝐛subscript𝐈𝑑superscript𝐀𝐀𝐰\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}+(\mathbf{I}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{w} for some 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathds{R}^{d}, where 𝐀+superscript𝐀\mathbf{A}^{+} denotes the pseudoinverse of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} satisfying the Moore-Penrose conditions[14]777When 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} has linearly independent rows, we have 𝐀+=𝐀T​(𝐀𝐀T)−1superscript𝐀superscript𝐀𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝐀𝑇1\mathbf{A}^{+}=\mathbf{A}^{T}(\mathbf{AA}^{T})^{-1}.. One property of pseudoinverse that is useful in the sequel is that if 𝐀=𝐔​𝚺​𝐕T𝐀𝐔𝚺superscript𝐕𝑇\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{U\Sigma V}^{T} is a singular value decomposition (SVD) of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}, then 𝐀+=𝐕​𝚺+​𝐔Tsuperscript𝐀𝐕superscript𝚺superscript𝐔𝑇\mathbf{A}^{+}=\mathbf{V\Sigma}^{+}\mathbf{U}^{T}, in which 𝚺+superscript𝚺\mathbf{\Sigma}^{+} is obtained by taking the reciprocal of each non-zero element on the diagonal of 𝚺𝚺\mathbf{\Sigma}, and then transposing the matrix.

For a given pair (𝐀,𝐛)𝐀𝐛(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{b}), define

𝒮≜{𝐱∈ℝd|𝐀𝐱=𝐛},𝒮ℱ≜{𝐱∈𝒮∩[0,1]d},formulae-sequence≜𝒮conditional-set𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑𝐀𝐱𝐛≜subscript𝒮ℱ𝐱𝒮superscript01𝑑\mathcal{S}\triangleq\bigg{\{}\mathbf{x}\in\mathds{R}^{d}\bigg{|}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}\bigg{\}}\ ,\ \mathcal{S_{F}}\triangleq\bigg{\{}\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{S}\cap[0,1]^{d}\bigg{\}}, (8)

as the solution space and feasible solution space, respectively. Alternatively, by defining

𝒲≜{𝐰∈ℝd|−𝐀+​𝐛≤(𝐈d−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐰≤𝟏d−𝐀+​𝐛},≜𝒲conditional-set𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐀𝐛subscript𝐈𝑑superscript𝐀𝐀𝐰subscript1𝑑superscript𝐀𝐛\mathcal{W}\triangleq\bigg{\{}\mathbf{w}\in\mathds{R}^{d}\bigg{|}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}\leq(\mathbf{I}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{w}\leq\mathbf{1}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}\bigg{\}}, (9)

we have

𝒮ℱ={(𝐈d−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐰+𝐀+​𝐛|𝐰∈𝒲}.subscript𝒮ℱconditional-setsubscript𝐈𝑑superscript𝐀𝐀𝐰superscript𝐀𝐛𝐰𝒲\mathcal{S_{F}}=\bigg{\{}(\mathbf{I}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{w}+\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}\bigg{|}\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}\bigg{\}}. (10)

We have that 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is a closed and bounded convex set defined as an intersection of 2​d2𝑑2d half-spaces. Since 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} is the image of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} under an affine transformation, it is a closed convex polytope in [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}.

For a general (satisfiable or not) system of linear equations 𝐂𝐱=𝐝𝐂𝐱𝐝\mathbf{Cx}=\mathbf{d}, we have that 𝐂+​𝐝=arg​min𝐱⁡‖𝐂𝐱−𝐝‖2superscript𝐂𝐝subscriptargmin𝐱subscriptnorm𝐂𝐱𝐝2\mathbf{C}^{+}\mathbf{d}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbf{x}}\|\mathbf{Cx}-\mathbf{d}\|_{2}. Moreover, if the system is satisfiable, the quantity 𝐂+​𝐝superscript𝐂𝐝\mathbf{C}^{+}\mathbf{d} is the minimum L2superscript𝐿2L^{2}-norm solution. Therefore, in our problem, we have ‖𝐱‖2≥‖𝐀+​𝐛‖2subscriptnorm𝐱2subscriptnormsuperscript𝐀𝐛2\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}\geq\|\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}\|_{2} for all 𝐱∈𝒮𝐱𝒮\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{S}. Define 𝐱^LS≜𝐀+​𝐛≜subscript^𝐱LSsuperscript𝐀𝐛\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{\textnormal{LS}}\triangleq\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}, where the subscripts stands for Least Square888Note that this naming is with a slight abuse of convention, as the term least square points to a vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} that minimizes ‖𝐀𝐱−𝐛‖2subscriptnorm𝐀𝐱𝐛2\|\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{b}\|_{2} in general, rather than a minimum norm solution.. It is important to note that 𝐱^LSsubscript^𝐱LS\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{\textnormal{LS}} may not necessarily belong to 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}}, which is our region of interest. A geometrical representation for the case (m,d)=(1,3)𝑚𝑑13(m,d)=(1,3) is provided in Figure 2. As a result, one can always consider the constrained optimization min𝐱⁡‖𝐀𝐱−𝐛‖2subscript𝐱subscriptnorm𝐀𝐱𝐛2\min_{\mathbf{x}}\|\mathbf{A}\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{b}\|_{2} with the constraint 𝟎d≤𝐱≤𝟏dsubscript0𝑑𝐱subscript1𝑑\mathbf{0}_{d}\leq\mathbf{x}\leq\mathbf{1}_{d} in order to find a feasible solution. We denote any solution obtained in this manner by 𝐱^CLSsubscript^𝐱CLS\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{\textnormal{CLS}}, where the subscript stands for Constrained Least Square. In an indeterminate system, in contrast to 𝐱^LSsubscript^𝐱LS\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{\textnormal{LS}}, 𝐱^CLSsubscript^𝐱CLS\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{\textnormal{CLS}} is not unique, and any point in 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} can be a candidate for 𝐱^CLSsubscript^𝐱CLS\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{\textnormal{CLS}} depending on the initial point of the solver.

Consider this simple example that x𝑥x is an unknown quantity in the range [0,1]01[0,1] to be estimated and the error in the estimation is measured by the mean square, i.e., |x−x^|2superscript𝑥^𝑥2|x-\hat{x}|^{2}. Obviously, any point in [0,1]01[0,1] can be proposed as an estimate for x𝑥x. However, without any further knowledge about x𝑥x, one can select the center of [0,1]01[0,1], i.e., 1212\frac{1}{2} as an intuitive estimate. The rationale behind this selection is that the maximum error of the estimate x^=12^𝑥12\hat{x}=\frac{1}{2}, i.e., maxx⁡|x−12|2subscript𝑥superscript𝑥122\max_{x}|x-\frac{1}{2}|^{2} is minimal among all other estimates. In other words, the center minimizes the worst possible estimation error, and hence, it is optimal in the best-worst sense. As mentioned earlier, any element of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} is a feasible solution of 𝐀𝐱=𝐛𝐀𝐱𝐛\mathbf{Ax}=\mathbf{b}. This calls for a proper definition of the ”center” of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} as the best-worst solution. This is called the Chebyshev center which is introduced in a general topological context as follows.

Definition 1.

(Chebyshev Center [15]) Let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} be a bounded subset of a metric space (𝒳,d)𝒳𝑑(\mathcal{X},d), where d𝑑d denotes the distance. A Chebyshev center of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is the center of minimal closed ball containing 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, i.e., it is an element x𝒬∈𝒳subscript𝑥𝒬𝒳x_{\mathcal{Q}}\in\mathcal{X} such that supu∈𝒬d​(x𝒬,u)=infx∈𝒳supu∈𝒬d​(x,u)subscriptsupremum𝑢𝒬𝑑subscript𝑥𝒬𝑢subscriptinfimum𝑥𝒳subscriptsupremum𝑢𝒬𝑑𝑥𝑢\sup_{u\in\mathcal{Q}}d(x_{\mathcal{Q}},u)=\inf_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\sup_{u\in\mathcal{Q}}d(x,u). The quantity r​(𝒬)≜infx∈𝒳supu∈𝒬d​(x,u)≜𝑟𝒬subscriptinfimum𝑥𝒳subscriptsupremum𝑢𝒬𝑑𝑥𝑢r(\mathcal{Q})\triangleq\inf_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\sup_{u\in\mathcal{Q}}d(x,u) is the Chebyshev radius of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}.

In this paper, the metric space under consideration is (ℝd,∥⋅∥2)(\mathds{R}^{d},\|\cdot\|_{2}) for some positive integer d𝑑d, and we have

𝐱𝒬≜arg​min𝐱^∈ℝd⁡max𝐱∈𝒬⁡‖𝐱−𝐱^‖22.≜subscript𝐱𝒬subscriptargmin^𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝐱𝒬superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐱^𝐱22\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{Q}}\triangleq\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathds{R}^{d}}\max_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{Q}}\|\mathbf{x}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\|_{2}^{2}. (11)

For example the Chebyshev center of [0,1]01[0,1] in (ℝ,∥⋅∥2)(\mathds{R},\|\cdot\|_{2}) is 1212\frac{1}{2}, and the Chebyshev center of the ball {𝐫∈ℝ2|‖𝐫‖≤1}conditional-set𝐫superscriptℝ2norm𝐫1\{\mathbf{r}\in\mathds{R}^{2}|\|\mathbf{r}\|\leq 1\} in (ℝ2,∥⋅∥2)(\mathds{R}^{2},\|\cdot\|_{2}) is the origin999Note that the Chebyshev center of the circle {𝐫∈ℝ2|‖𝐫‖=1}conditional-set𝐫superscriptℝ2norm𝐫1\{\mathbf{r}\in\mathds{R}^{2}|\|\mathbf{r}\|=1\} in the same metric is still the origin, but obviously it does not belong to the circle, as the circle is not convex in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathds{R}^{2}.

In this paper, the subset of interest, i.e., 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} (=𝒮ℱabsentsubscript𝒮ℱ=\mathcal{S_{F}}), is bounded, closed and convex. In this context, the Chebyshev center of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is unique and belongs to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. Hence, in the argmin in (11), 𝐱^∈ℝd^𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathds{R}^{d} can be replaced with 𝐱^∈𝒬^𝐱𝒬\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{Q}. An example is provided in Figure 3.

Except for simple cases, computing the Chebyshev center is a computationally complex problem due to the non-convex quadratic inner maximization in (11). When the subset of interest, i.e., 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, can be written as the convex hull of a finite number of points, there are algorithms [16, 17] that can find the Chebyshev center. In this paper, 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}(=𝒮ℱabsentsubscript𝒮ℱ=\mathcal{S_{F}}) is a convex polytope with a finite number of extreme points (as shown in Figure 2), hence, one can apply these algorithms. However, it is important to note that these extreme points are not given a priori and they need to be found in the first place from the equation 𝐀𝐱=𝐛𝐀𝐱𝐛\mathbf{Ax}=\mathbf{b}. Since the procedure of finding the extreme points of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} is exponentially complex, it makes sense to seek approximations for the Chebyshev center that can be handled efficiently. Therefore, in this paper, instead of obtaining the exact Chebyshev center of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}}, we rely on its approximations. A nice approximation worth mentioning is given in [18], which is in the context of signal processing and is explained in the sequel. This approximation is based on replacing the non-convex inner maximization in (11) by its semidefinite relaxation, and then solving the resulting convex-concave minimax problem. A clear explanation of this method, henceforth named Relaxed Chebyshev Center 1 (RCC1), is needed because it is used as one of the adversary’s attack methods in this paper. Later, in proposition 3, a second relaxation is proposed, which is denoted as RCC2.

The set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} in [18] is an intersection of k𝑘k ellipsoids, i.e.,

𝒬≜{𝐱|fi​(𝐱)≜𝐱T​𝐐i​𝐱+2​𝐠iT​𝐱+ti≤0,i∈[k]},≜𝒬conditional-set𝐱formulae-sequence≜subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱superscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝐐𝑖𝐱2superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑇𝐱subscript𝑡𝑖0𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\mathcal{Q}\triangleq\{\mathbf{x}|f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\triangleq\mathbf{x}^{T}\mathbf{Q}_{i}\mathbf{x}+2\mathbf{g}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{x}+t_{i}\leq 0,i\in[k]\}, (12)

where 𝐐i⪰0,𝐠i∈ℝd,ti∈ℝformulae-sequencesucceeds-or-equalssubscript𝐐𝑖0formulae-sequencesubscript𝐠𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑡𝑖ℝ\mathbf{Q}_{i}\succeq 0,\mathbf{g}_{i}\in\mathds{R}^{d},t_{i}\in\mathds{R}, and the optimization problem is given in (11). Defining 𝚫≜𝐱𝐱T≜𝚫superscript𝐱𝐱𝑇\mathbf{\Delta}\triangleq\mathbf{x}\mathbf{x}^{T}, the equivalence holds

max𝐱∈𝒬⁡‖𝐱−𝐱^‖2=max(𝚫,𝐱)∈𝒢⁡{‖𝐱^‖2−2​𝐱^T​𝐱+Tr​(𝚫)},subscript𝐱𝒬superscriptnorm𝐱^𝐱2subscript𝚫𝐱𝒢superscriptnorm^𝐱22superscript^𝐱𝑇𝐱Tr𝚫\max_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{Q}}\|\mathbf{x}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\|^{2}=\max_{(\mathbf{\Delta,x})\in\mathcal{G}}\{\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\|^{2}-2\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{T}\mathbf{x}+\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{\Delta})\}, (13)

where 𝒢={(𝚫,𝐱)|Tr​(𝐐i​𝚫)+2​𝐠iT​𝐱+ti≤0,i∈[k],𝚫=𝐱𝐱T}𝒢conditional-set𝚫𝐱formulae-sequenceTrsubscript𝐐𝑖𝚫2superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑇𝐱subscript𝑡𝑖0formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑘𝚫superscript𝐱𝐱𝑇\mathcal{G}=\{(\mathbf{\Delta,x})|\ \textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{Q}_{i}\mathbf{\Delta})+2\mathbf{g}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{x}+t_{i}\leq 0,i\in[k],\mathbf{\Delta}=\mathbf{x}\mathbf{x}^{T}\}. By focusing on the right hand side (RHS) of (13) instead of its left hand side (LHS), we are now dealing with the maximization of a concave (linear) function in (𝚫,𝐱)𝚫𝐱(\mathbf{\Delta,x}). However, the downside is that 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is not convex, in contrast to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. Here is where the relaxation is done in [18], and the optimization is carried out over a relaxed version of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, i.e.,

𝒯={(𝚫,𝐱)|Tr​(𝐐i​𝚫)+2​𝐠iT​𝐱+ti≤0,i∈[k],𝚫⪰𝐱𝐱T},𝒯conditional-set𝚫𝐱formulae-sequenceTrsubscript𝐐𝑖𝚫2superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑇𝐱subscript𝑡𝑖0formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑘succeeds-or-equals𝚫superscript𝐱𝐱𝑇\mathcal{T}=\{(\mathbf{\Delta,x})|\ \textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{Q}_{i}\mathbf{\Delta})+2\mathbf{g}_{i}^{T}\mathbf{x}+t_{i}\leq 0,i\in[k],\mathbf{\Delta}\succeq\mathbf{x}\mathbf{x}^{T}\},

which is a convex set, and obviously 𝒢⊂𝒯𝒢𝒯\mathcal{G}\subset\mathcal{T}. As a results, RCC1 is the solution to the following minimax problem

min𝐱^⁡max(𝚫,𝐱)∈𝒯⁡{‖𝐱^‖2−2​𝐱^T​𝐱+Tr​(𝚫)}.subscript^𝐱subscript𝚫𝐱𝒯superscriptnorm^𝐱22superscript^𝐱𝑇𝐱Tr𝚫\min_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\max_{(\mathbf{\Delta,x})\in\mathcal{T}}\{\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\|^{2}-2\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{T}\mathbf{x}+\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{\Delta})\}. (14)

Since 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is bounded, and the objective in (14) is convex in 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} and concave (linear) in (𝚫,𝐱)𝚫𝐱(\mathbf{\Delta,x}), the order of minimization and maximization can be changed. Knowing that the minimum (over 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}) of the objective function occurs at 𝐱^=𝐱^𝐱𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}=\mathbf{x}, (14) reduces to

max(𝚫,𝐱)∈𝒯⁡{−‖𝐱‖2+Tr​(𝚫)},subscript𝚫𝐱𝒯superscriptnorm𝐱2Tr𝚫\max_{(\mathbf{\Delta,x})\in\mathcal{T}}\{-\|{\mathbf{x}}\|^{2}+\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{\Delta})\},

whose objective is concave and the constraints are linear matrrix inequalities, and RCC1 is the 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}-part of the solution. Since 𝒢⊂𝒯𝒢𝒯\mathcal{G}\subset\mathcal{T}, the radius of the corresponding ball of RCC1 is an upperbound on r​(𝒬)𝑟𝒬r(\mathcal{Q}), i.e., the Chebyshev radius of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}.

An explicit representation of 𝐱RCC1subscript𝐱RCC1\mathbf{x}_{\textnormal{RCC1}} is given in [18, Theorem III.1], which is restated here.

𝐱RCC1=−(∑i=1kαi​𝐐i)−1​(∑i=1kαi​𝐠i),subscript𝐱RCC1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝐐𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝐠𝑖\mathbf{x}_{\textnormal{RCC1}}=-\bigg{(}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\alpha_{i}\mathbf{Q}_{i}\bigg{)}^{-1}\bigg{(}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\alpha_{i}\mathbf{g}_{i}\bigg{)}, (15)

where (α1,…,αk)subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑘(\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{k}) is an optimal solution of the following convex problem

which can be cast as a semidefinite program (SDP) and solved by an SDP solver.

It is shown in [18] that similarly to the exact Chebyshev center, 𝐱RCC1subscript𝐱RCC1\mathbf{x}_{\textnormal{RCC1}} is also unique (due to strict convexity of the L2superscript𝐿2L^{2}-norm) and it belongs to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, where the latter follows from the fact that for any (𝚫′,𝐱′)∈𝒯superscript𝚫′superscript𝐱′𝒯(\mathbf{\Delta}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{T}, we have 𝐱′∈𝒬superscript𝐱′𝒬\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Q}, which is due to the positive semidefiniteness of 𝐐i,i∈[k]subscript𝐐𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\mathbf{Q}_{i},i\in[k].

Finally, suppose that one of the constraints defining the set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is a double-sided linear inequality of the form l≤𝐚T​𝐱≤u𝑙superscript𝐚𝑇𝐱𝑢l\leq\mathbf{a}^{T}\mathbf{x}\leq u. We can proceed and write this constraint as two constraints, i.e., 𝐚T​𝐱≤usuperscript𝐚𝑇𝐱𝑢\mathbf{a}^{T}\mathbf{x}\leq u and −𝐚T​𝐱≤−lsuperscript𝐚𝑇𝐱𝑙-\mathbf{a}^{T}\mathbf{x}\leq-l. However, it is shown in [18] that it is better (in the sense of a smaller minimax estimate) to write it in the quadratic form, i.e., (𝐚T​𝐱−l)​(𝐚T​𝐱−u)≤0superscript𝐚𝑇𝐱𝑙superscript𝐚𝑇𝐱𝑢0(\mathbf{a}^{T}\mathbf{x}-l)(\mathbf{a}^{T}\mathbf{x}-u)\leq 0. Although the exact Chebyshev center of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} does not rely on its specific representation, the RCC1 does, as it is the result of a relaxation of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. Hence, any constraint of the form l≤𝐚T​𝐱≤u𝑙superscript𝐚𝑇𝐱𝑢l\leq\mathbf{a}^{T}\mathbf{x}\leq u will be replaced by 𝐱T​𝐐𝐱+2​𝐠T​𝐱+t≤0superscript𝐱𝑇𝐐𝐱2superscript𝐠𝑇𝐱𝑡0\mathbf{x}^{T}\mathbf{Q}\mathbf{x}+2\mathbf{g}^{T}\mathbf{x}+t\leq 0, with 𝐐=𝐚𝐚T,𝐠=−u+l2​𝐚formulae-sequence𝐐superscript𝐚𝐚𝑇𝐠𝑢𝑙2𝐚\mathbf{Q}=\mathbf{aa}^{T},\mathbf{g}=-\frac{u+l}{2}\mathbf{a}, and t=u​l𝑡𝑢𝑙t=ul.

The final discussion in this section is Von Neumann’s trace inequality [19], which is used throughout the paper. It states that for two n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n (complex) matrices 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A,B}, with singular values α1≥α2≥…≥αnsubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑛\alpha_{1}\geq\alpha_{2}\geq\ldots\geq\alpha_{n} and β1≥β2≥…≥βnsubscript𝛽1subscript𝛽2…subscript𝛽𝑛\beta_{1}\geq\beta_{2}\geq\ldots\geq\beta_{n}, respectively, we have

|Tr​(𝐀𝐁)|≤∑i=1nαi​βi.Tr𝐀𝐁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖|\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{AB})|\leq\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}\beta_{i}. (17)

If 𝐀,𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A,B} are symmetric positive semidefinite matrices with eigenvalues a1≥a2≥…≥ansubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2…subscript𝑎𝑛a_{1}\geq a_{2}\geq\ldots\geq a_{n} and b1≥b2≥…≥bnsubscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2…subscript𝑏𝑛b_{1}\geq b_{2}\geq\ldots\geq b_{n}, respectively, we have

∑i=1nai​bn−i+1≤Tr​(𝐀𝐁)≤∑i=1nai​bi.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑛𝑖1Tr𝐀𝐁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}b_{n-i+1}\leq\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{AB})\leq\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}b_{i}. (18)

V White-box setting

Let X∈[0,1]𝑋01X\in[0,1] be a random variable distributed according to an unknown CDF FXsubscript𝐹𝑋F_{X}. The goal is to find an estimate X^^𝑋\hat{X}. First, we need the following lemma, which states that when there is no side information available to the estimator, there is no loss of optimality in restricting to the set of deterministic estimates.

Lemma 1.

Any randomized guess is outperformed by its statistical mean, and the performance improvement is equal to the variance of the random guess.

Proof.

Let X^^𝑋\hat{X} be a random guess distributed according to a fixed CDF FX^subscript𝐹^𝑋F_{\hat{X}}. We have

𝔼​[(X−X^)2]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑋^𝑋2\displaystyle\mathds{E}[(X-\hat{X})^{2}] =𝔼​[(X−𝔼​[X^])2]+Var​(X^)absent𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑋𝔼delimited-[]^𝑋2Var^𝑋\displaystyle=\mathds{E}[(X-\mathds{E}[\hat{X}])^{2}]+\textnormal{Var}(\hat{X})
≥𝔼​[(X−𝔼​[X^])2].absent𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑋𝔼delimited-[]^𝑋2\displaystyle\geq\mathds{E}[(X-\mathds{E}[\hat{X}])^{2}].

Hence, any estimate X^∼FX^similar-to^𝑋subscript𝐹^𝑋\hat{X}\sim F_{\hat{X}} is outperformed by the new deterministic estimate 𝔼​[X^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝑋\mathds{E}[\hat{X}], whose performance improvement is Var​(X^)Var^𝑋\textnormal{Var}(\hat{X}). ∎

Since the underlying distribution of X𝑋X is unknown to the estimator, one conventional approach is to consider the best-worst estimator. In other words, the goal of the estimator is to minimize the maximum error, which can be cast as a minimax problem, i.e.,

minx^⁡maxFX⁡𝔼​[(X−x^)2],subscript^𝑥subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑋𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑋^𝑥2\min_{\hat{x}}\max_{F_{X}}\mathds{E}[(X-\hat{x})^{2}], (19)

where lemma 1 is used in the minimization, i.e., instead of minimizing over FX^subscript𝐹^𝑋F_{\hat{X}}, we are minimizing over the singleton x^^𝑥\hat{x}. Since for any fixed x^^𝑥\hat{x}, we have maxFX𝔼[(X−x^)2]=maxx∈[0,1](x−x^)2\max_{F_{X}}\mathds{E}[(X-\hat{x})^{2}]=\max_{x\in[0,1]}(x-\hat{x})^{2}, the best-worst estimation is the solution to

minx^maxx∈[0,1](x−x^)2,\min_{\hat{x}}\max_{x\in[0,1]}(x-\hat{x})^{2}, (20)

which is the Chebyshev center of the interval [0,1]01[0,1] in the space (ℝ,∥⋅∥2)(\mathds{R},\|\cdot\|_{2}) and it is equal to 1212\frac{1}{2}. This implies that with the estimator being blind to the underlying distribution and any possible side information, the best-worst estimate is the Chebyshev center of the support of the random variable, here [0,1]01[0,1].

As one step further, consider that 𝐗∈[0,1]d𝐗superscript01𝑑\mathbf{X}\in[0,1]^{d} is a d𝑑d-dimensional random vector distributed according to an unknown CDF F𝐗subscript𝐹𝐗F_{\mathbf{X}}. Although the estimator is still unaware of F𝐗subscript𝐹𝐗F_{\mathbf{X}}, this time it has access to the matrix-vector pair (𝐀,𝐀𝐗)𝐀𝐀𝐗(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{AX}), and based on this side information, it gives an estimate 𝐗^^𝐗\hat{\mathbf{X}}. This side information refines the prior belief of 𝐗∈[0,1]d𝐗superscript01𝑑\mathbf{X}\in[0,1]^{d} to 𝐗∈𝒮ℱ𝐗subscript𝒮ℱ\mathbf{X}\in\mathcal{S_{F}}. Similarly to the previous discussion, the best-worst estimator gives the Chebyshev center of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}}. As mentioned before, obtaining the exact Chebyshev centre of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} is computationally difficult, hence, we focus on its approximations. However, prior to the approximation, we start with simple heuristic estimates that bear an intuitive notion of centeredness.

The first scheme in estimating 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, is the naive estimate of 12​𝟏d12subscript1𝑑\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}, which is the Chebyshev center of [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}. We name this estimate as 𝐗^half=12​𝟏dsubscript^𝐗half12subscript1𝑑\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}}=\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}. We already know that when the only information that we have about 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is that it belongs to [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}, then 𝐗^halfsubscript^𝐗half\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}} is optimal in the best-worst sense.

The adversary can perform better when the side information (𝐀𝐗,𝐀)𝐀𝐗𝐀(\mathbf{AX},\mathbf{A}) is available. A second scheme can be built on top of the previous scheme as follows. The estimator finds a solution in the solution space, i.e., 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, that is closest to 12​𝟏d12subscript1𝑑\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}, which is shown in Figure 2. In this scheme, the estimate, named 𝐗^half∗subscript^𝐗superscripthalf\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}, is given by

𝐗^half∗≜arg​min𝐱∈𝒮⁡‖𝐱−12​𝟏d‖2,≜subscript^𝐗superscripthalfsubscriptargmin𝐱𝒮superscriptnorm𝐱12subscript1𝑑2\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}\triangleq\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{S}}\|{\mathbf{x}}-\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}\|^{2}, (21)

Thus far, we have considered two simple schemes, i.e., 𝐗^halfsubscript^𝐗half\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}} and 𝐗^half∗subscript^𝐗superscripthalf\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}. arg​min𝐱^∈𝒮ℱ⁡max𝐱∈𝒮ℱ⁡‖𝐱−𝐱^‖2.subscriptargmin^𝐱subscript𝒮ℱsubscript𝐱subscript𝒮ℱsuperscriptnorm𝐱^𝐱2\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{S_{F}}}\max_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{S_{F}}}\|\mathbf{x}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\|^{2}. (28)

Let 𝐀=𝐔​𝚺​𝐕T𝐀𝐔𝚺superscript𝐕𝑇\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{U\Sigma V}^{T} be an SVD of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}, where the singular values are arranged in a non-increasing order, i.e., σ1≥σ2≥σ3​…subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2subscript𝜎3…\sigma_{1}\geq\sigma_{2}\geq\sigma_{3}\ldots. Let r≜rank​(𝐀)≜𝑟rank𝐀r\triangleq\textnormal{rank}(\mathbf{A}). Define 𝐖≜[𝐯r+1,𝐯r+2,…,𝐯d]d×(d−r)≜𝐖subscriptsubscript𝐯𝑟1subscript𝐯𝑟2…subscript𝐯𝑑𝑑𝑑𝑟\mathbf{W}\triangleq[\mathbf{v}_{r+1},\mathbf{v}_{r+2},\ldots,\mathbf{v}_{d}]_{d\times(d-r)}.

The orthonormal columns of 𝐕𝐕\mathbf{V} can be regarded as a basis for ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathds{R}^{d}. =𝐖𝐖T.absentsuperscript𝐖𝐖𝑇\displaystyle=\mathbf{WW}^{T}.

𝒮ℱ={𝐀+​𝐛+𝐖𝐮|𝐮∈𝒮ℱ~},𝒮ℱ~≜{𝐮∈ℝ(d−r)|−𝐀+​𝐛≤𝐖𝐮≤𝟏−𝐀+​𝐛}.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒮ℱconditional-setsuperscript𝐀𝐛𝐖𝐮𝐮~subscript𝒮ℱ≜~subscript𝒮ℱconditional-set𝐮superscriptℝ𝑑𝑟superscript𝐀𝐛𝐖𝐮1superscript𝐀𝐛\mathcal{S_{F}}=\{\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}+\mathbf{Wu}|\mathbf{u}\in\tilde{\mathcal{S_{F}}}\},\ \tilde{\mathcal{S_{F}}}\triangleq\{\mathbf{u}\in\mathds{R}^{(d-r)}|-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}\leq\mathbf{Wu}\leq\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}\}. (29)

Therefore,

min𝐱^∈𝒮ℱ⁡max𝐱∈𝒮ℱ⁡‖𝐱−𝐱^‖2subscript^𝐱subscript𝒮ℱsubscript𝐱subscript𝒮ℱsuperscriptnorm𝐱^𝐱2\displaystyle\min_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{S_{F}}}\max_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{S_{F}}}\|\mathbf{x}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\|^{2} =min𝐮^∈𝒮ℱ~⁡max𝐮∈𝒮ℱ~⁡‖𝐀+​𝐛+𝐖𝐮−𝐀+​𝐛−𝐖​𝐮^‖2absentsubscript^𝐮~subscript𝒮ℱsubscript𝐮~subscript𝒮ℱsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝐀𝐛𝐖𝐮superscript𝐀𝐛𝐖^𝐮2\displaystyle=\min_{\hat{\mathbf{u}}\in\tilde{\mathcal{S_{F}}}}\max_{\mathbf{u}\in\tilde{\mathcal{S_{F}}}}\|\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}+\mathbf{Wu}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{W\hat{u}}\|^{2}

Denoting the i𝑖i-th row of 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and the i𝑖i-th element of 𝐀+​𝐛superscript𝐀𝐛\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b} by 𝐚iTsuperscriptsubscript𝐚𝑖𝑇\mathbf{a}_{i}^{T} and qi,i∈[d]subscript𝑞𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑑q_{i},i\in[d], respectively, the following proposition provides an approximation for the exact Chebyshev center in (28).

Proposition 2.

A relaxed Chebyshev center of 𝒮ℱsubscript𝒮ℱ\mathcal{S_{F}} is given by

‖𝐗−𝐗^half‖2superscriptnorm𝐗subscript^𝐗half2\displaystyle\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}}\|^{2} =‖𝐗−𝐗^half∗‖2+‖𝐗^half∗−𝐗^half‖2absentsuperscriptnorm𝐗subscript^𝐗superscripthalf2superscriptnormsubscript^𝐗superscripthalfsubscript^𝐗half2\displaystyle=\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}\|^{2}+\|\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}}\|^{2}
≥‖𝐗−𝐗^half∗‖2,absentsuperscriptnorm𝐗subscript^𝐗superscripthalf2\displaystyle\geq\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}\|^{2}, (48)

and by taking the expectation, we get

MSE​(𝐗^half∗)≤MSE​(𝐗^half).MSEsubscript^𝐗superscripthalfMSEsubscript^𝐗half\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}})\leq\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}}). (49)

∎

Remark 2.

Remark 3.

From Theorem 2, the passive party can obtain the MSE of the attacks 𝐗^LSsubscript^𝐗LS\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}} and 𝐗^half∗subscript^𝐗superscripthalf\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}} as closed form solutions. It is important to note that in this context, this is still possible although the passive party is unaware of the active party’s model parameters and the confidence scores it receives. We also note that according to remark 1, although the adversary has multiple ways to obtain a system of linear equations, all of them are equivalent. As a result, the passive party can assume that the adversary has obtained this system in a particular way, and obtain the MSE. In other words, regardless of whether the adversary is dealing with 𝐀𝐗=𝐛𝐀𝐗𝐛\mathbf{AX}=\mathbf{b} or 𝐀new​𝐗=𝐛newsubscript𝐀new𝐗subscript𝐛new\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{b}_{\textnormal{new}}, with 𝐀new=𝐑𝐀subscript𝐀new𝐑𝐀\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}=\mathbf{RA} and 𝐛n​e​w=𝐑𝐛subscript𝐛𝑛𝑒𝑤𝐑𝐛\mathbf{b}_{new}=\mathbf{Rb} for arbitrary invertible 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R}, we have (𝐈−𝐀+​𝐀)=(𝐈−𝐀new+​𝐀new)𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀𝐈superscriptsubscript𝐀newsubscript𝐀new(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})=(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}^{+}\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}), which results from i) 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R} is invertible and ii) 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} has linearly independent rows, and hence (𝐑𝐀)+=𝐀+​𝐑+=𝐀+​𝐑−1superscript𝐑𝐀superscript𝐀superscript𝐑superscript𝐀superscript𝐑1(\mathbf{RA})^{+}=\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{R}^{+}=\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{R}^{-1}.

Remark 4.

In many practical scenarios, we have that 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} is either full column or full row rank, which results in rank​(𝐀)=min⁡{k−1,d}rank𝐀𝑘1𝑑\textnormal{rank}(\mathbf{A})=\min\{k-1,d\} (and hence nul​(𝐀)=max⁡{d−k+1,0}nul𝐀𝑑𝑘10\textnormal{nul}(\mathbf{A})=\max\{d-k+1,0\}), where k𝑘k denotes the number of classes. In this context, the importance of the lower and upper bounds in (50) and (51) is that the passive party can calculate them prior to the training, which can be carried out by calculating the eigenvalues of 𝐊𝟎subscript𝐊0\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}} and 𝐊12​𝟏subscript𝐊121\mathbf{K}_{\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}}.

Remark 5.

The attack schemes proposed in this section are applied per prediction, i.e., an estimate is obtained after the receipt of the confidence scores for each sample in the prediction set. It is easy to verify that these attacks result in the same performance if applied on multiple predictions. More specifically, assuming that there are N𝑁N predictions, the resulting system of linear equations is 𝐀𝐗=𝐛𝐀𝐗𝐛\mathbf{AX}=\mathbf{b}, in which 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is an N​d𝑁𝑑Nd-dimensional vector obtained as the concatenation of N𝑁N d𝑑d-dimensional vectors, 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} is N​(k−1)×N​d𝑁𝑘1𝑁𝑑N(k-1)\times Nd-dimensional, and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} is N​(k−1)𝑁𝑘1N(k-1)-dimensional. Nonetheless, all the attack methods discussed, do not improve by being applied on multiple predictions.

VI Black-box setting

A relaxed version of the black-box setting is considered in [11], in which the adversary is aware of some auxiliary data, i.e., the passive party’s features for some sample IDs, and based on these auxiliary data, the adversary estimates the passive party’s model parameters. Once this estimate is obtained, any reconstruction attack in the white-box setting can be applied by regarding this estimate as the true model parameters. Needless to say that all the proposed attacks in the previous section of this paper can be applied in this way. However, the real black-box setting in which the adversary cannot have access to auxiliary data remains open. In what follows, we investigate this problem under specific circumstances.

Here, we assume that the passive party has only one feature denoted by Xi∈[0,1],i∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑖01𝑖delimited-[]𝑁X_{i}\in[0,1],i\in[N], corresponding to N𝑁N predictions. We assume that (X1,X2,…,XN)subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋𝑁(X_{1},X_{2},\ldots,X_{N}) are i.i.d. according to an unknown CDF FXsubscript𝐹𝑋F_{X}. In the black-box setting, the adversary observes vi=ω​Xi+b,i∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖𝜔subscript𝑋𝑖𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝑁v_{i}=\omega X_{i}+b,i\in[N], where ω𝜔\omega (≠0absent0\neq 0) and b𝑏b are unknown. This is a specific case of (6), where d=1𝑑1d=1. A question that arises here is : How is the performance of the adversary affected by the lack of knowledge about ω,b𝜔𝑏\omega,b? In other words, what (minimal) knowledge about ω,b𝜔𝑏\omega,b is sufficient for the adversary in order to perform a successful reconstruction attack in estimating (X1,X2,…,XN)subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋𝑁(X_{1},X_{2},\ldots,X_{N})? In what follows, it is shown that in certain scenarios, this lack of knowledge has a vanishing effect given that N𝑁N is large enough.

Lemma 2.

Assume that (X1,X2,…,XN)subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋𝑁(X_{1},X_{2},\ldots,X_{N}) are i.i.d. according to an unknown CDF FXsubscript𝐹𝑋F_{X}, where Xi∈[0,1],i∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑖01𝑖delimited-[]𝑁X_{i}\in[0,1],i\in[N]. Fix an arbitrary ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1). We have

limN→∞Pr​{maxi∈[N]⁡Xi≤1−ϵ}subscript→𝑁Prsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝑋𝑖1italic-ϵ\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}\textnormal{Pr}\left\{\max_{i\in[N]}X_{i}\leq 1-\epsilon\right\} =0absent0\displaystyle=0

(74) is the application of Boole’s inequality, i.e., the union bound, and finally, (75) results from lemma 2.

Again, the empirical MSE of the adversary converges in probability to 0, which means that in this context, the lack of knowledge of the parameters has a vanishingly small effect.

VI-C Case 3: ω​b<0𝜔𝑏0\omega b<0

In this case, the observations of the adversary are vi=ω​Xi+b,i∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑖𝜔subscript𝑋𝑖𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝑁v_{i}=\omega X_{i}+b,i\in[N], where ω𝜔\omega and b𝑏b have different signs. This case is more involved and can be divided into two scenarios as follows.

VI-C1 All the visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}’s have the same sign

In this case, the adversary concludes that the sign of b𝑏b is the same as that of visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}’s, since if N𝑁N is large enough, for some i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], we have Xi≈0subscript𝑋𝑖0X_{i}\approx 0 and its corresponding visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} is close to b𝑏b. Also, since we have ω​b<0𝜔𝑏0\omega b<0, the sign of ω𝜔\omega is inferred. Now that the signs of ω𝜔\omega and b𝑏b are known to the adversary, following a similar approach as in the previous subsection, it can be shown that MSE converges in probability to 0.

VI-C2 The visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}’s do not have the same sign

In this case, the adversary cannot decide between ω>0,b<0formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑏0\omega>0,b<0 and ω<0,b>0formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑏0\omega<0,b>0. It is, however, easy to show that in one case the adversary’s estimates are close to the real values, i.e., X^i≈Xi,i∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscript^𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\hat{X}_{i}\approx X_{i},i\in[N], and in the other case X^i≈1−Xisubscript^𝑋𝑖1subscript𝑋𝑖\hat{X}_{i}\approx 1-X_{i}. Not knowing which of the two cases is true, one approach is that the adversary can assume ω>0,b<0formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑏0\omega>0,b<0 for the first N2𝑁2\frac{N}{2} predictions and obtain estimates accordingly, and for the second N2𝑁2\frac{N}{2} predictions, it assumes ω<0,b>0formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑏0\omega<0,b>0 and obtain estimates accordingly. The error of the adversary is close to 0 in one of these batches of N2𝑁2\frac{N}{2} predictions. However, this approach can be outperformed as follows. The adversary assumes for the whole N𝑁N predictions that ω>0,b<0formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑏0\omega>0,b<0 and obtains estimates accordingly. Afterwards, the adversary assumes ω<0,b>0formulae-sequence𝜔0𝑏0\omega<0,b>0 for the whole N𝑁N predictions, and obtains a second estimate. Since MSE is a strictly convex function of the estimate, X^i≈12​Xi+12​(1−Xi)=12subscript^𝑋𝑖12subscript𝑋𝑖121subscript𝑋𝑖12\hat{X}_{i}\approx\frac{1}{2}X_{i}+\frac{1}{2}(1-X_{i})=\frac{1}{2} outperforms the previous approach, which means that the aforementioned estimation is worse than the naive estimate of 1212\frac{1}{2}. Weather the adversary can beat this estimate in this context is left as a problem to be consider in a later study.151515In this context, one possible approach is to use the population statistics publicly available to the active party. For instance, if the unknown feature is the age of each client, the active party can use the population average as an estimate in solving ω​∑iXiN+b=∑iviN𝜔subscript𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖𝑁𝑏subscript𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖𝑁\omega\frac{\sum_{i}X_{i}}{N}+b=\frac{\sum_{i}v_{i}}{N}.

In conclusion, if the active party is aware of only the signs of ω𝜔\omega and b𝑏b, the attack has an error that vanishes with N𝑁N. If the adversary is only aware of the sign of ω​b𝜔𝑏\omega b, the same result holds unless the observations visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}’s have different signs.

VII Privacy-Preserving Scheme (PPS)

In [10] and [11], several defense techniques, such as differentially-private training, processing the confidence scores, etc., have been investigated, where the model accuracy is taken as the utility in a privacy-utility trade-off. Experimental results are provided to compare different techniques. Except for the two techniques, purification and rounding, defense comes with a loss in utility, i.e., the model accuracy is degraded.

This section consists of two subsections. In the first one, we consider the problem of preserving the privacy in the most stringent scenario, i.e., without altering the confidence scores that are revealed to the active party. In the second subsection, this condition is relaxed, and we focus on privacy-preserving schemes that do not degrade the model accuracy.

VII-A privacy preserving without changing the confidence scores

In this subsection, the question is: Is it possible to improve the privacy of the passive party, or equivalently worsen the performance of the adversary in doing reconstruction attacks, without altering the confidence scores that the active party receives? This refers to the stringent case where the active party requires the true soft confidence scores for decision making rather than the noisy or hard ones, i.e., class labels. One motivation for this requirement is provided in the following exmple. Consider the binary classification case, in which the active party is a bank that needs to decide whether to approve a credit request or not. Assuming that this party can approve a limited number of requests, it would make sense to receive the soft confidence scores for a better decision making. In other words, if the corresponding confidence scores for two sample IDs are (0.6,0.4)0.60.4(0.6,0.4) and (0.9,0.1)0.90.1(0.9,0.1), where each pair refers to the probabilities corresponding to (Approve, Disapprove) classes, the second sample ID has the priority for being approved. This ability to prioritize the samples would disappear if only a binary score is revealed to the active party. Hence, we wish to design a scheme that worsens the reconstruction attacks, while the disclosed confidence scores remain unaltered.

Before answering this question, we start with a simple example to introduce the main idea, and gradually build upon this. Consider a binary classification task with a logistic regression model. Moreover, assume that the training samples are 222-dimensional, i.e., 𝐱i=(x1,i,x2,i)T,i∈[n]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐱𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑖subscript𝑥2𝑖𝑇𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\mathbf{x}_{i}=(x_{1,i},x_{2,i})^{T},i\in[n] with n𝑛n denoting the number of elements in the training dataset 𝒟trainsubscript𝒟train\mathcal{D}_{\textnormal{train}}. By training the classifier, the model parameters ω0=(ω10,ω20)Tsubscript𝜔0superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜔10superscriptsubscript𝜔20𝑇\mathbf{\omega}_{0}=(\omega_{1}^{0},\omega_{2}^{0})^{T} and b0subscript𝑏0b_{0} are obtained such that c1=σ​(ω0T​𝐱+b0)=11+e−ω0T​𝐱−b0subscript𝑐1𝜎superscriptsubscript𝜔0𝑇𝐱subscript𝑏011superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝜔0𝑇𝐱subscript𝑏0c_{1}=\sigma(\mathbf{\omega}_{0}^{T}\mathbf{x}+b_{0})=\frac{1}{1+e^{-\mathbf{\omega}_{0}^{T}\mathbf{x}-b_{0}}} denotes the probability that 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} belongs to class 1, and obviously c2=1−c1subscript𝑐21subscript𝑐1c_{2}=1-c_{1}.

Proof.

This linear invariance observed in proposition 4 can be used in the design of a privacy-preserving scheme as follows. Consider the VFL discussed in this paper in the context of the white-box setting. Hence, the adversary knows 𝐖0subscript𝐖0\mathbf{W}_{0} (corresponding to the passive party’s model) and when the number of classes are greater than the number of passive party’s features, the latter can be perfectly reconstructed by the adversary resulting in MSE=0MSE0\textnormal{MSE}=0, i.e., the maximum privacy leakage. A privacy-preserving method that does not alter the confidence scores is proposed as follows. Select an arbitrary orthonormal matrix 𝐇d×d(≠𝐈d)annotatedsubscript𝐇𝑑𝑑absentsubscript𝐈𝑑\mathbf{H}_{d\times d}(\neq\mathbf{I}_{d}), and the passive party, instead of performing the training on its original training set 𝒟trainsubscript𝒟train\mathcal{D}_{\textnormal{train}}, trains the model on 𝒟trainnewsuperscriptsubscript𝒟trainnew\mathcal{D}_{\textnormal{train}}^{\textnormal{new}} where the new samples are the linear transformation (according to 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}) of the original samples. Note that the task of the active party in training remains unaltered, i.e., it contributes to the training as before. In the white-box scenario, the adversary is aware of the model parameters, and again with the same assumptions, i.e., when the number of classes are greater than the number of passive party’s features, the adversary can perfectly reconstruct 𝐱new(=𝐇𝐱)annotatedsubscript𝐱newabsent𝐇𝐱\mathbf{x}_{\textnormal{new}}(=\mathbf{Hx}). With this scheme, the adversary’s MSE has increased from 0 to 𝔼​[‖(𝐈−𝐇)​𝐗‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐈𝐇𝐗2\mathds{E}[\|(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{H})\mathbf{X}\|^{2}], which answers the question asked in the beginning of this section in the affirmative. What remains is to find an appropriate 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}. To this end, we propose a heuristic scheme in the sequel.

Any orthonormal 𝐇(≠𝐈)annotated𝐇absent𝐈\mathbf{H}(\neq\mathbf{I}) results in some level of protection for the passive party’s features. Therefore, the to propose the heuristic scheme, we first start with maximizing 𝔼​[‖(𝐈−𝐇)​𝐗‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐈𝐇𝐗2\mathds{E}[\|(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{H})\mathbf{X}\|^{2}] over the space of orthonormal matrices. Although the latter is not a convex set, this optimization has a simple solution. We have

From Von Neumann’s trace inequality, we have

|Tr​(𝐊𝟎​𝐇)|≤∑i=1dαi​βi=∑i=1dαi=Tr​(𝐊𝟎),Trsubscript𝐊0𝐇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝛼𝑖Trsubscript𝐊0\displaystyle|\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}\mathbf{H})|\leq\sum_{i=1}^{d}\alpha_{i}\beta_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\alpha_{i}=\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}), (80)

where (80) follows from the following facts: i) all the singular values of an orthonormal matrix are equal to 1161616This can be proved by noting that the singular values of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} are the absolute value of the square root of the eigenvalues of 𝐇T​𝐇superscript𝐇𝑇𝐇\mathbf{H}^{T}\mathbf{H} (=𝐈absent𝐈=\mathbf{I})., and ii) since 𝐊𝟎subscript𝐊0\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}} is symmetric and positive semidefinite, its singular values and eigenvalues coincide. This shows that 𝐇=−𝐈𝐇𝐈\mathbf{H}=-\mathbf{I} is a minimizer in (78).

The maximization in (77) is the MSE of the adversary when the number of features is lower than the number of classes. Otherwise, it would be a lower bound on the MSE since the adversary cannot reconstruct 𝐇𝐗𝐇𝐗\mathbf{HX} perfectly. From Theorem 2, the closed form solution of MSE​(𝐗^LS)MSEsubscript^𝐗LS\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}) is known. Although the passive party is generally unaware of what attack method the adversary employs, in what follows, we analyze the performance of 𝐗^LSsubscript^𝐗LS\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}} after the application of PPS, hence named 𝐗^LSPPSsuperscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPS\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}}.

Theorem 3.

We have

max𝐇:𝐇T​𝐇=𝐈MSE​(𝐗^LSPPS)=Tr​((𝐈+𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐊𝟎)+2​‖𝐀+​𝐀𝐊𝟎‖∗,subscript:𝐇absentsuperscript𝐇𝑇𝐇𝐈MSEsuperscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPSTr𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀subscript𝐊02subscriptnormsuperscript𝐀subscript𝐀𝐊0\max_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{H}:\\ \mathbf{H}^{T}\mathbf{H}=\mathbf{I}\end{subarray}}\ \ \textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}})=\textnormal{Tr}((\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}})+2\|\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}\|_{*}, (81)

where ∥⋅∥∗\|\cdot\|_{*} denotes the nuclear norm. Let 𝐔𝐒𝐕Tsuperscript𝐔𝐒𝐕𝑇\mathbf{US}\mathbf{V}^{T} be a singular value decomposition of 𝐀+​𝐀𝐊𝟎superscript𝐀subscript𝐀𝐊0\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}. We have that 𝐇∗=−𝐕𝐔Tsuperscript𝐇superscript𝐕𝐔𝑇\mathbf{H}^{*}=-\mathbf{VU}^{T} is a maximizer in (81).

Proof.

As already stated, after the application of PPS with the orthonormal matrix 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}, the new parameters are 𝐖0​𝐇−1subscript𝐖0superscript𝐇1\mathbf{W}_{0}\mathbf{H}^{-1} or equivalently 𝐖0​𝐇Tsubscript𝐖0superscript𝐇𝑇\mathbf{W}_{0}\mathbf{H}^{T}. As a result, the matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}, capturing the coefficients in the system of linear equations, changes to 𝐀𝐇−1superscript𝐀𝐇1\mathbf{A}\mathbf{H}^{-1}. Therefore, we can write

𝐗^LSPPS=(𝐀𝐇−1)+​(𝐀𝐇−1)​𝐇𝐗.superscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPSsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝐇1superscript𝐀𝐇1𝐇𝐗\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}}=(\mathbf{A}\mathbf{H}^{-1})^{+}(\mathbf{A}\mathbf{H}^{-1})\mathbf{HX}.

It is known that for two matrices 𝐁,𝐂𝐁𝐂\mathbf{B,C}, if 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} has orthonormal rows, then (𝐁𝐂)+=𝐂+​𝐁+superscript𝐁𝐂superscript𝐂superscript𝐁(\mathbf{BC})^{+}=\mathbf{C}^{+}\mathbf{B}^{+}. Since 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} is orthonormal, 𝐇−1superscript𝐇1\mathbf{H}^{-1} has orthonormal rows, and being invertible, we have (𝐇−1)+=𝐇superscriptsuperscript𝐇1𝐇(\mathbf{H}^{-1})^{+}=\mathbf{H}. Therefore, we can write

𝐗^LSPPS=𝐇𝐀+​𝐀𝐗,superscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPSsuperscript𝐇𝐀𝐀𝐗\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}}=\mathbf{H}\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{X},

which results in

MSE​(𝐗^LSPPS)MSEsuperscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPS\displaystyle\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}}) =𝔼​[‖𝐗−𝐗^LSPPS‖2]absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗superscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPS2\displaystyle=\mathds{E}[\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}}\|^{2}]
=𝔼​[‖(𝐈−𝐇𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐗‖2]absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐈superscript𝐇𝐀𝐀𝐗2\displaystyle=\mathds{E}[\|(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{H}\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{X}\|^{2}]

From (82), we have that maximizing MSE​(𝐗^LSPPS)MSEsuperscriptsubscript^𝐗LSPPS\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}^{\textnormal{PPS}}) is equivalent to minimizing Tr​(𝐇𝐀+​𝐀𝐊𝟎)Trsuperscript𝐇𝐀subscript𝐀𝐊0\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{H}\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}), since the first term in (82) does not depend on 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}. Let 𝐔𝐒𝐕Tsuperscript𝐔𝐒𝐕𝑇\mathbf{US}\mathbf{V}^{T} be a singular value decomposition of 𝐀+​𝐀𝐊𝟎superscript𝐀subscript𝐀𝐊0\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}. =−‖𝐀+​𝐀𝐊𝟎‖∗.absentsubscriptnormsuperscript𝐀subscript𝐀𝐊0\displaystyle=-\|\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}\|_{*}.

Finally, by noting that −𝐕𝐔Tsuperscript𝐕𝐔𝑇-\mathbf{VU}^{T} is orthonormal, the proof is complete. ∎

Note that when the number of features of the passive party is lower than the number of classes, we have 𝐀+​𝐀=𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀𝐈\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{I}. Therefore, 𝐀+​𝐀𝐊𝟎=𝐊𝟎=𝐐​𝚲​𝐐Tsuperscript𝐀subscript𝐀𝐊0subscript𝐊0𝐐𝚲superscript𝐐𝑇\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}=\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}=\mathbf{Q}\mathbf{\Lambda}\mathbf{Q}^{T}, and 𝐇∗=−𝐐𝐐T=−𝐈superscript𝐇superscript𝐐𝐐𝑇𝐈\mathbf{H}^{*}=-\mathbf{QQ}^{T}=-\mathbf{I}, which is in line with (77).

In summary, if the training is with regularization, we are sure that the new model parameters are a linear transform of the original ones, which is due to the strict convexity mentioned in proposition 4. As a result, we can worsen the adversary’s performance without altering the confidence scores that are revealed. However, if the training is without regularization, there is no guarantee that the new model parameters are a linear transform of the original ones171717unless we set the initial point of the solver close to the new model parameters, which is not practical as it requires to train twice., which is due to the possibility of having multiple solutions stated in proposition 4. In this case, although the confidence scores no longer remain the same, the new setting has the same empirical cost. In other words, the average cross entropy between the one-hot vector of the class labels and the confidence scores does not change, which is a relaxed version of our initial lossless utility.

Remark 6.

The main idea in this subsection was to train the VFL model on a linearly transformed data to worsen the adversary’s performance and preserve the fidelity in reporting confidence scores. This process can be viewed/implemented in a different way as follows. Consider that the training phase is on the original data, and the model parameters are obtained. Let 𝐖0subscript𝐖0\mathbf{W}_{0} denote the model parameters of the passive party. Instead of revealing 𝐖0subscript𝐖0\mathbf{W}_{0} to the active party, a manipulated version of it, i.e., 𝐖0​𝐇−1subscript𝐖0superscript𝐇1\mathbf{W}_{0}\mathbf{H}^{-1} is disclosed. The adversary regards this as the true model parameters, and all the attacks are performed accordingly. In other words, the same preservation of privacy has been switched from training on the linearly transformed data to revealing the linearly transformed parameters. In this context, the constraints that were initially imposed on 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} can be viewed as a measure which ensures that the new revealed model parameters are not ”far” from the original ones and have a one-to-one correspondence due to the invertibility of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}. This different but equivalent view of privacy enhancement can be regarded as a bridge between the white-box (revealing 𝐖0subscript𝐖0\mathbf{W}_{0}) and the black-box (revealing no model parameters) setting. Finally, this manipulation of the model parameters could also be done in an additive way, which is left as a problem to be investigated in future.

VII-B privacy preserving without changing the model accuracy

In this subsection, we relax the requirement of the previous subsection, and consider privacy-preserving schemes that change the confidence scores without changing the model accuracy. We focus on adding noise to the intermediate results as follows. The confidence score that the coordinator reveals to the adversary is given by 𝐜=σ​(𝐳)𝐜𝜎𝐳\mathbf{c}=\sigma(\mathbf{z}) with 𝐳=𝕎a​c​t​𝐘+𝕎p​a​s​𝐗+𝐛𝐳subscript𝕎𝑎𝑐𝑡𝐘subscript𝕎𝑝𝑎𝑠𝐗𝐛\mathbf{z}=\mathbb{W}_{act}\mathbf{Y}+\mathbb{W}_{pas}\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{b}. In order to preserve the privacy, we assume that the coordinator adds some noise to the intermediate results, i.e., 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}, before the application of softmax. In other words, the new confidence scores that are revealed to the adversary are

𝐜~=σ​(𝐳~)=σ​(𝐳+𝐧).~𝐜𝜎~𝐳𝜎𝐳𝐧\tilde{\mathbf{c}}=\sigma(\tilde{\mathbf{z}})=\sigma(\mathbf{z}+\mathbf{n}). (83)

Let 𝐒≜𝔼​[𝐧𝐧T]≜𝐒𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝐧𝐧𝑇\mathbf{S}\triangleq\mathds{E}[\mathbf{nn}^{T}] denote the correlation matrix of 𝐧𝐧\mathbf{n}, and Tr​(𝐒)Tr𝐒\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{S}) denotes the noise budget. In what follows, we obtain the MSE of 𝐗^LSsubscript^𝐗LS\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}, which sheds light on how to generate the additive noise 𝐧𝐧\mathbf{n}.

The noisy system of linear equations that the adversary constructs is a modified version of (5), which is obtained by replacing 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z} with 𝐳~~𝐳\tilde{\mathbf{z}} as

𝕁​𝕎p​a​s​𝕏𝕁subscript𝕎𝑝𝑎𝑠𝕏\displaystyle\mathbb{JW}_{pas}\mathbb{X} =𝐉​𝐳~−𝕁​𝕎a​c​t​𝐘−𝐉𝐛absent𝐉~𝐳𝕁subscript𝕎𝑎𝑐𝑡𝐘𝐉𝐛\displaystyle=\mathbf{J}\tilde{\mathbf{z}}-\mathbb{J}\mathbb{W}_{act}\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{Jb}
=𝐉𝐳−𝕁​𝕎a​c​t​𝐘−𝐉𝐛+𝐉𝐧,absent𝐉𝐳𝕁subscript𝕎𝑎𝑐𝑡𝐘𝐉𝐛𝐉𝐧\displaystyle=\mathbf{Jz}-\mathbb{J}\mathbb{W}_{act}\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{Jb}+\mathbf{Jn}, (84)

where 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J} is given in (4). As a result, instead of solving the correct system 𝐀𝐗=𝐛′𝐀𝐗superscript𝐛′\mathbf{AX}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}, the adversary tries to solve 𝐀𝐗=𝐛′~(=𝐛′+𝐉𝐧)𝐀𝐗annotated~superscript𝐛′absentsuperscript𝐛′𝐉𝐧\mathbf{AX}=\tilde{\mathbf{b}^{\prime}}(=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}+\mathbf{Jn}). Therefore, we have

𝐗^LS=𝐀+​𝐛′~=𝐀+​(𝐀𝐗+𝐉𝐧),subscript^𝐗LSsuperscript𝐀~superscript𝐛′superscript𝐀𝐀𝐗𝐉𝐧\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}=\mathbf{A}^{+}\tilde{\mathbf{b}^{\prime}}=\mathbf{A}^{+}(\mathbf{AX}+\mathbf{Jn}), (85)

and

MSE​(𝐗^LS)MSEsubscript^𝐗LS\displaystyle\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}) =1d​𝔼​[‖𝐗−𝐗^LS‖2]absent1𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗subscript^𝐗LS2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}[\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}\|^{2}]
=1d​𝔼​[‖𝐗−𝐀+​(𝐀𝐗+𝐉𝐧)‖2]absent1𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗superscript𝐀𝐀𝐗𝐉𝐧2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}[\|\mathbf{X}-\mathbf{A}^{+}(\mathbf{AX}+\mathbf{Jn})\|^{2}]

=1d​Tr​((𝐈−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐊𝟎)+1d​Tr​(𝐀+​𝐉𝐒𝐉T​𝐀+T),absent1𝑑Tr𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀subscript𝐊01𝑑Trsuperscript𝐀superscript𝐉𝐒𝐉𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}\textnormal{Tr}\left((\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}\right)+\frac{1}{d}\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{JSJ}^{T}{\mathbf{A}^{+}}^{T}), (86)

By comparing (86) to (50), we observe that the second term in (86), which is non-negative181818This follows the positive semidefiniteness of 𝐀+​𝐉𝐒𝐉T​𝐀+Tsuperscript𝐀superscript𝐉𝐒𝐉𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{JSJ}^{T}{\mathbf{A}^{+}}^{T}., represents the performance degradation due to the receipt of noisy confidence scores. Furthermore, this performance degradation depends on the additive noise only through its correlation matrix 𝐒𝐒\mathbf{S}.

It makes sense to maximize the MSE of the adversary subject to a limited noise budget, i.e.,

max𝐒:Tr​(𝐒)≤α⁡Tr​(𝐀+​𝐉𝐒𝐉T​𝐀+T)subscript:𝐒Tr𝐒𝛼Trsuperscript𝐀superscript𝐉𝐒𝐉𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇\max_{\mathbf{S}:\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{S})\leq\alpha}\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{JSJ}^{T}{\mathbf{A}^{+}}^{T}) (87)

for some α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0. However, we first need to show that the objective of this optimization does not depend on a specific choice of 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J}. This is crucial since the coordinator is unaware how the adversary constructs the system of linear equations. We already know that 𝐀=𝐉𝐖p​a​s𝐀subscript𝐉𝐖𝑝𝑎𝑠\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{JW}_{pas}, and for simplicity, we drop the subscript in the sequel, and use 𝐀=𝐉𝐖𝐀𝐉𝐖\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{JW} instead. The following lemma shows that replacing 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J} with 𝐑𝐉𝐑𝐉\mathbf{RJ}, in which 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R} is invertible, does not change the objective in (87). As a result, the coordinator can assume that the system of linear equations has been obtained by 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J} and perform the optimization in (87).

Lemma 3.

For an invertible 𝐑(k−1)×(k−1)subscript𝐑𝑘1𝑘1\mathbf{R}_{(k-1)\times(k-1)}, we have

Tr​((𝐑𝐉𝐖)+​𝐑𝐉𝐒​(𝐑𝐉)T​(𝐑𝐉𝐖)+T)=Tr​((𝐉𝐖)+​𝐉𝐒𝐉T​(𝐉𝐖)+T).Trsuperscript𝐑𝐉𝐖𝐑𝐉𝐒superscript𝐑𝐉𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐑𝐉𝐖𝑇Trsuperscript𝐉𝐖superscript𝐉𝐒𝐉𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐉𝐖𝑇\textnormal{Tr}\left((\mathbf{RJW})^{+}\mathbf{RJS}(\mathbf{RJ})^{T}{(\mathbf{RJW})^{+}}^{T}\right)=\textnormal{Tr}\left((\mathbf{JW})^{+}\mathbf{JS}\mathbf{J}^{T}{(\mathbf{JW})^{+}}^{T}\right).
Proof.

Since 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R} is invertible, it has linearly independent columns. Moreover, since 𝐉𝐖𝐉𝐖\mathbf{JW} has linearly independent rows, we have (𝐑𝐉𝐖)+=(𝐉𝐖)+​𝐑+=(𝐉𝐖)+​𝐑−1superscript𝐑𝐉𝐖superscript𝐉𝐖superscript𝐑superscript𝐉𝐖superscript𝐑1(\mathbf{RJW})^{+}=(\mathbf{JW})^{+}\mathbf{R}^{+}=(\mathbf{JW})^{+}\mathbf{R}^{-1}. Using this and the fact that (𝐀𝐁)T=𝐁T​𝐀Tsuperscript𝐀𝐁𝑇superscript𝐁𝑇superscript𝐀𝑇(\mathbf{AB})^{T}=\mathbf{B}^{T}\mathbf{A}^{T} concludes the proof. ∎

Let 𝐀+​𝐉=𝐔​𝚺​𝐕Tsuperscript𝐀𝐉𝐔𝚺superscript𝐕𝑇\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{U\Sigma V}^{T} be a singular value decomposition in which the singular values are arranged in a non-increasing order, i.e., σ1≥σ2≥…subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2…\sigma_{1}\geq\sigma_{2}\geq\ldots .

We have

Thus far, the coordinator knows that the additive noise 𝐧𝐧\mathbf{n} in (83) should have a correlation matrix equal to α​𝐯1​𝐯1T𝛼subscript𝐯1superscriptsubscript𝐯1𝑇\alpha\mathbf{v}_{1}\mathbf{v}_{1}^{T}. Before further analysis, we need to be aware of two points. The first one is that the MSE in (86) does not assume that 𝐗^LSsubscript^𝐗LS\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}} has been clamped to [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}. As a result, it can grow unboundedly with α𝛼\alpha, as concluded from theorem 4. However, in practice, the adversary can simply truncate its estimate to the region of interest, and hence, the results of theorem 4 can be used as a hint on how to add noise to the intermediate results. The second point that is worth mentioning here is that we are interested in adding noise in a way that it does not degrade the model accuracy. This requires that the same entry that is maximum in 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z} should also be the maximum in 𝐳~~𝐳\tilde{\mathbf{z}}.

In what follows, taking into account the aforementioned points, we propose two privacy-preserving schemes that preserve the model accuracy while worsening the adversary’s performance. The first scheme is as follows. In each prediction, the coordinator finds the index of the entry that is maximum in 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}, i.e.,

and reveals 𝐜~=σ​(𝐳+𝐧)~𝐜𝜎𝐳𝐧\tilde{\mathbf{c}}=\sigma(\mathbf{z}+\mathbf{n}) to the adversary.

The above schemes can be viewed alternatively as follows. In each prediction, the adversary has the random error of
